results.title: A Secret war room
results.creator_credit: Joan Peck, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Joan Peck served in the WAAAF as a radio telephone operator at Number one fighter sector in Preston. Their main role was to connect the army, navy and airforce in one central control to help protect and defend the Victorian coastline. Peck used state of the art technology at work, yet didn’t even have a telephone at home. Her highly secretive and crucial work at the centre was often interspersed with a spot of knitting.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Peck, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: My brother's birthday
results.creator_credit: Max Hammond, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: In Syria, on the way to Beirut, Max Hammond’s thoughts turned to his family. One of seven children, Hammond and his three brothers served together in World War II. He recounts a close call that occurred on his brother’s birthday and reflects on how lucky he and his brothers are.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Max Hammond, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: John Miles: drafted Vietnam
results.brief_description: John Miles recalls the 29th of September 1965 as the date that he commenced his National Service. While he was away, the political climate changed dramatically in Australia. Miles remembers his experience of the Vietnam War and his struggles once home in Australia. Miles’ treatment on return to Australia initially made left him feeling bitter, but a trip back to Vietnam was crucial to his personal transformation and healing.
results.description: John Miles recalls the 29th of September 1965 as the date that he commenced his National Service. While he was away, the political climate changed dramatically in Australia. Miles remembers his experience of the Vietnam War and his struggles once home in Australia. results.title: Interview with Ben Whitham
results.brief_description: In war, you are discouraged from keeping records or taking photographs. However, soldiers broke those rules in order to help remember. Born on a small soldier’s settlement farm, Ben Witham grew up hearing stories about the war. Having a father who served in Gallipoli, to his own service in World War II, Witham recalls the camaraderie and the lighter side of war. He emphasises the bonds of fellow servicemen and the celebration of this during commemorations for ANZACs.

results.title: A Boy called "Rabbit"
results.creator_credit: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ken Cumming’s dearest memory of the time he served in Vietnam was a young boy by the name of “Rabbit”. While “Rabbit” couldn’t speak English, he was popular with the Australian soldiers for his fast running and bravery.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Java: island of volcanoes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indonesia”.
Showing life in Java, the rich and varied agricultural economy, which thrives in the lush tropical climate and Djakarta, the large bustling capital city of both the island and the nation. The film also depicts the numerous volcanoes of the island and discusses their significance to the people living near them. Narrated by Roger Climpson.

results.title: Sumatra: island of rice and rubber
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indonesia”
Scenes of life in Sumatra, one of the many islands of Indonesia. Shows the agricultural development and methods used by the rural population. Village life style and customs are also seen.

results.title: Bali: island of magic
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indonesia”.
Bali is one of the many Indonesian islands, but it differs from the other Muslim islands in that the people are mainly Hindu, with some Buddhists and an underlying interest in nature worship and even roots of ancient nature worship. Shows the daily life of the Balinese, which is governed by a voluntary village council, the farming and fishing, the market and the monkey dance. Narrated by Roger Climpson. No other credits available.
